elements.content: {[La(trans-DAM)(cis-DAM)(H2O)2](ClO4)·3H2O} n (1), {[La2(trans-DAM)3(H2O)6](OH)3·7H2O} n (2), {[La(trans-DAM)2(H2O)2]Cl·4H2O} n (3), {[Nd(trans-DAM)2(H2O)2]X·3H2O} n (X = ClO4 (4), NO3 (5)), {[Nd(trans-DAM)(cis-DAM)(H2O)2]Cl·5H2O} n (6), and {[Nd(trans-DAM)2(H2O)2]Cl·5H2O} n (7) incorporating a flexible ligand HDAM (N,N′-diacetic acid imidazolium) were prepared in H2O or H2O/DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide) solvents. Compounds 1 and 2 both contain the same 2D corrugated layers bridged by DAM− with different bridging modes to form different 3D structures, exhibiting tcs and (4,6)-connected topologies, respectively. The structural differences of 1 and 2 lie in the linkages of DAM− between the layers. Compound 3 also possesses a 3D architecture with an ant net, which is pillared by 2D (4,4) fan-shaped layers in an −ABAB− sequence. Compounds 4−6 contain similar 2D layers to 1 and 2. The analogous cationic structures 4 and 5 show a 4-connected sql net and 6 presents a (4,5)-connected network, resulting from the different modes of flag-like DAM− above and below the layers. Compound 7 with identical molecular formula to 6 displays a 2D double-layer, consisting of a couple of (4,4) rectangular grid layers. It exhibits a (3,6)-connected network. Additionally, IR and UV−visible spectroscopy, the luminescent properties, and thermogravimetric analyses are discussed.

elements.content: A series of various La(III) and Nd(III) compounds were prepared with a flexible ligand, HDMA (N,N′-diacetic acid imidazolium) in H2O or H2O/DMF solvents at the same pH value. The diversity of the coordination modes of DMA− induces these compounds to adopt different frameworks with novel topologies.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) containing lanthanide ions have attracted intense interest for the many potential applications in magnetic materials, molecular recognition, luminescent sensors and probes, photovoltaic conversion, laser systems, and photocatalysis. For instance, some Pr(III), Nd(III) and Yb(III) compounds, emitting in the near-infrared region, could be good candidate in medical diagnostics and two-photon fluorescence imaging for the longer emission wavelengths. Moreover, because of the unique nature of lanthanide ions (the large radius, high coordination numbers, and variable coordination geometry), lanthanide compounds usually exhibit fascinating frameworks and intriguing highly connected topologies. However, the design and synthesis of such MOFs still remains a great challenge. Besides the metal ions, the final structures are influenced by various factors, such as organic ligands, the metal/ligand ratios, counteranions, solvent preference, pH values, and the temperature. Among these factors, the structural characteristics of organic ligands play a vital role, which many reports show.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) containing lanthanide ions have attracted intense interest for the many potential applications in magnetic materials, molecular recognition, luminescent sensors and probes, photovoltaic conversion, laser systems, and photocatalysis. For instance, some Pr(III), Nd(III) and Yb(III) compounds, emitting in the near-infrared region, could be good candidate in medical diagnostics and two-photon fluorescence imaging for the longer emission wavelengths. Moreover, because of the unique nature of lanthanide ions (the large radius, high coordination numbers, and variable coordination geometry), lanthanide compounds usually exhibit fascinating frameworks and intriguing highly connected topologies. However, the design and synthesis of such MOFs still remains a great challenge. Besides the metal ions, the final structures are influenced by various factors, such as organic ligands, the metal/ligand ratios, counteranions, solvent preference, pH values, and the temperature. Among these factors, the structural characteristics of organic ligands play a vital role, which many reports show.

elements.content: Recently, we have focused on a flexible ligand, N,N′-diacetic acid imidazolium (HDAM), as a powerful ionic liquid precursor, which is composed of the imidazolium cation bearing carboxylate groups. Some reports indicated that HDAM not only is used as a reaction media in synthesis but also has potential as a multifunctional organic link to form MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have focused on a flexible ligand, N,N'-diacetic acid imidazolium (HDAM), as a powerful ionic liquid precursor, which is composed of the imidazolium cation bearing carboxylate groups. Some reports indicated that HDAM not only is used as a reaction media in synthesis but also has potential as a multifunctional organic link to form MOFs.

elements.content: Indeed, HDAM has many remarkable features. It contains two carboxylate groups, which can provide many coordination modes, from terminal monodentate to various bridging modes. In addition, depending on the degree of deprotonation, they can act as hydrogen bond acceptors and donors to benefit the formation of supramolecular structures. On the other hand, due to the presence of −CH2− spacers between the imidazole and carboxylate groups, HDAM has many degrees of flexibility and conformational freedom by bending or rotation when coordinating to the metal center to give entanglements, conformational polymorphism, and supramolecular isomerism, which may provide more possibility for the construction of unprecedented connected topological frameworks. However, to the best of our knowledge, the lanthanide MOFs with the flexible HDAM have not been reported to date, in comparison with some group I and II and transitional metal compounds.

However, to the best of our knowledge, the lanthanide MOFs with the flexible HDAM have not been reported to date, in comparison with some group I and II and transitional metal compounds.

elements.content: We selected LnX3 (Ln = La, Nd; X = ClO4 −, NO3 −, or Cl−) and HDAM in different solvents (H2O or H2O/DMF) under the same pH value to prepare a series of lanthanide compounds at room temperature. With abundant coordination modes of DAM−, three La(III) compounds, 1−3, adopt 3D frameworks with noninterpenetrating topologies, and four Nd(III) compounds, 4−7, exhibit 2D layers. IR and UV−visible spectroscopy, the luminescent properties, and thermal stability were also investigated.

With abundant coordination modes of DAM-, three La(III) compounds, 1-3, adopt 3D frameworks with noninterpenetrating topologies, and four Nd(III) compounds, 4-7, exhibit 2D layers. IR and UV-visible spectroscopy, the luminescent properties, and thermal stability were also investigated.

elements.content: The ligands HDAM were prepared according to the reported procedures. Other reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed with an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The powder XRD patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X′pert Pro diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. IR spectra were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 using the KBr pellet technique. UV−visible double resonance ionization spectroscopy (DRIS) were measured by a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV−vis spectrometer with BaSO4 as the reference sample. The solid-state luminescent spectra were carried out on an Edinburgh Instrument FL/FS-920 fluorescent spectrometer using a Xe lamp. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under N2 atmosphere at 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TGA 7.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The ligands HDAM were prepared according to the reported procedures. Other reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed with an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The powder XRD patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X'pert Pro diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature. IR spectra were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 using the KBr pellet technique. UV-visible double resonance ionization spectroscopy (DRIS) were measured by a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV-vis spectrometer with BaSO4 as the reference sample. The solid-state luminescent spectra were carried out on an Edinburgh Instrument FL/FS-920 fluorescent spectrometer using a Xe lamp. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under N2 atmosphere at 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C/min on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TGA 7.

A mixture of La(ClO4)3·6H2O (0.2 mmol) and HDAM (0.5 mmol) was added to 5.0 mL H2O. The pH value was adjusted to 3.0 with HClO4 (1.0 mol/L) and KOH (1.0 mol/L). elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements for 1−7 were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD area detector. Intensity data were collected by a graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) using a ω scan mode at 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method. All non-hydrogen atoms, except some disordered carbon atoms (C10A, C10B, and C10C in 2) and several guest water molecules (O13 and O14 in 2; O16, O17A, O17B, and O17C in 4; O15, O16, and O16′ in 5, as well as O13, O13′, O14, O14′, O15, and O15′ in 7), were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms on C atoms were positioned geometrically and the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located in Fourier difference maps. The guest water molecules mentioned above were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. All calculations were performed on a computer with SHELXTL-PC program package. Crystallographic data for the structures reported have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC reference numbers 741725−741731 for 1−7. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Further details of the crystallographic data and structure refinement for 1−7 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths for 1−7 are listed in Table S1.

X-Ray Crystallography

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements for 1-7 were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD area detector. Intensity data were collected by a graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a ω scan mode at 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program. The structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method. All non-hydrogen atoms, except some disordered carbon atoms (C10A, C10B, and C10C in 2) and several guest water molecules (O13 and O14 in 2; O16, O17A, O17B, and O17C in 4; O15, O16, and O16' in 5, as well as O13, O13', O14, O14', O15, and O15' in 7), were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms on C atoms were positioned geometrically and the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located in Fourier difference maps. The guest water molecules mentioned above were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. All calculations were performed on a computer with SHELXTL-PC program package. Crystallographic data for the structures reported have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC reference numbers 741725-741731 for 1-7. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Further details of the crystallographic data and structure refinement for 1-7 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths for 1-7 are listed in Table S1.

All compounds were obtained at the pH value 3.0. Compounds 1, 2, and 4−6 were prepared in H2O solvent reaction and 3 and 7 were obtained from a H2O/DMF mixed solvent system. The DAM− ligands display eight coordination modes as trans or cis conformation in 1−7, which are exhibited in Scheme . Except the modes in parts a−c, the others are first reported for the HDAM ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

All compounds were obtained at the pH value 3.0. Compounds 1, 2, and 4-6 were prepared in H2O solvent reaction and 3 and 7 were obtained from a H2O/DMF mixed solvent system. The DAM- ligands display eight coordination modes as trans or cis conformation in 1-7, which are exhibited in Scheme . Except the modes in parts a-c, the others are first reported for the HDAM ligand.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 possesses a 3D architecture with 3D intersected channels. The asymmetric unit consists of one La(III) ion, one-half of a trans-DAM−, one-half of a cis-DAM−, one coordinated water molecule, one-half of a ClO4 − anion and one and one-half guest water molecules. The 10-coordinated La ion is surrounded by oxygen atoms from four trans-DAM−, two cis-DAM−, and two water molecules to furnish a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry (Figure a). The bond lengths of La−O vary from 2.514(2) to 2.812(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported in other La(III) compounds.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 possesses a 3D architecture with 3D intersected channels. The asymmetric unit consists of one La(III) ion, one-half of a trans-DAM-, one-half of a cis-DAM-, one coordinated water molecule, one-half of a ClO4 - anion and one and one-half guest water molecules. The 10-coordinated La ion is surrounded by oxygen atoms from four trans-DAM-, two cis-DAM-, and two water molecules to furnish a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry (Figure a). The bond lengths of La-O vary from 2.514(2) to 2.812(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported in other La(III) compounds.

elements.content: The coordination modes of trans-DAM− and cis-DAM− are displayed in Scheme , parts a and b, respectively. Both carboxylate groups of each trans-DAM− exhibit one kind of bridging mode, μ2-η1:η2, and both carboxylate groups of each cis-DAM− show the μ1-η0:η1 mode. In detail, La ions in 1 are doubly bridged by μ-O3 from trans-DAM− to form a [La2O2] chain running along the a axis, in which the shortest La···La distance is 4.608(6) Å. The neighboring [La2O2] chains are connected by μ4-trans-DAM− to generate 2D corrugated layers (Figure b) on the ac plane, which are further linked by μ2-cis-DAM− to form an open framework with 3D infinite intersected channels (Figure c,d). The dimensions of the largest channels are approximately 10.347 Å × 10.347 Å along the c axis. All of the channels are occupied by the counteranions ClO4 − and guest water molecules. There are strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated oxygen atoms of cis-DAM− with the O···O distances in the range of 2.769(3)−2.967(1) Å (Figure S1, ). The effective free volume of the channels without these guest molecules is estimated to be 790.4 Å3 by PLATON software, almost 31.2% of the per unit cell volume of 2530.2 Å3.

elements.content: In order to investigate the nature of the structure, topological analysis by TOPOS4.0 was applied to reduce multidimensional structures to simple net. Each La ion in 1 connected by six DAM− can be treated as a 5-connected node for two cis-DAM− acting as one linker. Each trans-DAM− is regarded as a 4-connected node. Such connectivity repeats infinitely, resulting in a novel binodal (4,5)-connected tcs net (Figure e) with the Schläfli symbol (44·62)(44·66) (the first symbol for trans-DAM− and the second one for La ions). Among the reported topologies, unlike the 3-, 4-, or 6-connected topologies, 5-connected networks are relatively scarce. Particularly, only several examples with (4,5)-connected networks have been reported to date.

elements.content: The structure of 2 also can be described as a complicated 3D framework, including two kinds of crystallographically independent trans-DAM− ligands. The asymmetric unit of 2 is completed by one La(III) ion, one trans-DAM− (i), one-half of a trans-DAM− (ii), two coordinated water molecules, one and one-half OH− anions and three and one-half guest water molecules. Similar to 1, La ion exhibits a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry in Figure a coordinated with four trans-DAM− (i), two trans-DAM− (ii), and two water molecules. The bond lengths of La−O are in the range of 2.514(3)−2.770(3) Å, which are comparable to those in similar La(III) compounds.

The structure of 2 also can be described as a complicated 3D framework, including two kinds of crystallographically independent trans-DAM- ligands. The asymmetric unit of 2 is completed by one La(III) ion, one trans-DAM- (i), one-half of a trans-DAM- (ii), two coordinated water molecules, one and one-half OH- anions and three and one-half guest water molecules. Similar to 1, La ion exhibits a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry in Figure a coordinated with four trans-DAM- (i), two trans-DAM- (ii), and two water molecules. The bond lengths of La-O are in the range of 2.514(3)-2.770(3) Å, which are comparable to those in similar La(III) compounds.

elements.content: The trans-DAM− (i) shows the same bis-μ2-η1:η2 mode (Scheme a) as that in 1. The same 2D corrugated layers on the ac plane are also observed in 2 with the shortest La···La distance being 4.439(8) Å. However, different from 1, there are no cis-DAM− ligands, and both carboxylate groups of the other trans-DAM− (ii) in 2 adopt the μ2-η1:η1 bridging mode (Scheme c). The 2D layers are cross-linked by the μ4-trans-DAM− (ii) to give a 3D framework (Figure b) with 2D rhombic channels, which propagate infinitely along the a and c axes with the sizes of approximately 9.049 Å × 7.459 Å and 10.298 Å × 7.439 Å, respectively (Figure c). Furthermore, the structure is stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the guest molecules in the channels with O···O distances of 2.762(8)−3.118(8) Å (Table S2 and Figure S2, ). After removal of these molecules in the channels, the effective free volume is approximately 33.0% of the crystal volume (686.2 Å3 out of the 2081.3 Å3 per unit cell volume) by PLATON.

elements.content: Topologically, each La ion connected by six DAM− can be regarded as a 6-connected node in 2, since the coordinated water molecules do not contribute the topology. Meanwhile, the trans-DAM− (i) and (ii) with different μ4-modes are regarded as two kinds of 4-connected nodes. Finally, the 3D framework exhibits a novel trinodal (4,6)-connected topology with the Schläfli symbol (44·62)2(42·84)(48·66·8)2 (the first symbol for trans-DAM− (i), the second one for trans-DAM− (ii) and the third one for La ions) (Figure d). To our knowledge, it is a new topological structure.

elements.content: Compound 3 shows a different 3D framework from 1 and 2, because of the unique coordination mode of DAM−. There are one La(III) ion, one trans-DAM−, one coordinated water molecule, one-half of a Cl− anion, and two guest water molecules in the asymmetrical unit. As shown in Figure a, the center La ion is bonded by ten oxygen atoms from six equivalent trans-DAM− and two water molecules in a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry. The bond lengths of La−O vary from 2.504(3) to 2.796(3) Å, which are comparable to those of other La(III) compounds.

elements.content: Scheme d depicts the different coordination modes of carboxylate groups of the unique trans-DAM−in 3: μ2-η1:η2 and μ1-η0:η1. It is interesting that each La ion is connected by four trans-DAM− in μ3-mode to generate a 2D (4,4) fan-shaped grid layer on the ab plane (Figure b). These layers are further pillared via sharing the μ-O3 of trans-DAM− in an −ABAB− sequence to form a 3D structure with the shortest Nd···Nd distance of 4.556(6) Å, and each layer is central symmetrical to the next one, as presented in Figure c. There are 1D honeycomb channels of 10.899 Å × 10.658 Å along the c axis in 3 (Figure d), where the anion Cl− and guest water molecules are consolidated through hydrogen bonds with the O···O and O···Cl distances in the range of 2.782(8)−3.222(5) Å and 2.814(0) Å, respectively (Table S2 and Figure S3, ). The hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the disordered water molecules have not been discussed here. On the basis of a PLATON calculation, the framework of 3 possesses a 752.7 Å3 (29.9% of the whole unit cell volume 2520.2 Å3) solvent-accessible void space without the counteranions and guest water molecules.

The hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the disordered water molecules have not been discussed here. On the basis of a PLATON calculation, the framework of 3 possesses a 752.7 Å3 (29.9% of the whole unit cell volume 2520.2 Å3) solvent-accessible void space without the counteranions and guest water molecules.

elements.content: As mentioned above, each La ion is coordinated with six μ3-trans-DAM− in 3. According to the simplification principle, each La ion and trans-DAM− can be considered as 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively. Topology analysis suggests the structure is a binodal (3,6)-connected network with the Schläfli symbol (42·6)2(44·62·88·10) (the first symbol for trans-DAM− and the second one for La ions) (Figure e). The topology of 3 is ascribed to an ant net.

elements.content: Compounds 4 and 5 feature the analogous cationic 2D layer with different anions, hence, only the structure of 5 will be discussed in detail as a representation. The asymmetric unit of 5 comprises one Nd(III) ion, two crystallographically independent trans-DAM−, two coordinated water molecules, one NO3 − anion, and three guest water molecules. The coordination environment of Nd ion is completed by nine oxygen atoms from four trans-DAM− (i), one trans-DAM− (ii), and two water molecules in a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry (Figure a). The bond lengths of Nd−O are in the range of 2.320(2)−2.616(2) Å (for 4) and 2.335(6)−2.615(5) Å (for 5), which are comparable to those other Nd(III) compounds.

Compounds 4 and 5 feature the analogous cationic 2D layer with different anions, hence, only the structure of 5 will be discussed in detail as a representation. The asymmetric unit of 5 comprises one Nd(III) ion, two crystallographically independent trans-DAM-, two coordinated water molecules, one NO3 - anion, and three guest water molecules. The coordination environment of Nd ion is completed by nine oxygen atoms from four trans-DAM- (i), one trans-DAM- (ii), and two water molecules in a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry (Figure a). The bond lengths of Nd-O are in the range of 2.320(2)-2.616(2) Å (for 4) and 2.335(6)-2.615(5) Å (for 5), which are comparable to those other Nd(III) compounds.

elements.content: The trans-DAM− (i) adopts the μ4-mode with two μ2-η1:η2 carboxylate groups (Scheme a), whereas the trans-DAM−(ii) displays a new coordination type, where one carboxylate group exhibits the μ1-η0:η1 mode and the other deprotonated carboxylate group does not participate in the coordinated interactions (Scheme e). Similar to 1, the trans-DAM− (i) bridge [Nd2O2] chains, which are connected by the bridging μ-O5 atoms, in μ4-mode to establish a 2D corrugated layer on the ab plane with the shortest Nd···Nd distance of 4.350(5) Å. However, the 2D layer structure has no opportunity to be extended for the μ1-trans-DAM− (ii), which just locate above and below the layers like flags (Figure b). The adjacent layers are packed in an −AAAA− sequence (Figure c) into a 3D supramolecular framework by O−H···O hydrogen bonds between water molecules, the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the trans-DAM− (ii), and the counteranions (ClO4 − or NO3 −) with the O···O distances in the range of 2.665(9)−3.260(5) Å (for 4) and 2.641(0)−2.952(8) Å (for 5) (Table S2, Figures S4 and S5, ). The hydrogen bond interactions involving the disordered water molecules have not been added.

elements.content: With smaller counteranions Cl−, compound 6 also shows a corrugated 2D-layer structure. The asymmetric unit contains one Nd(III) ion, one trans-DAM−, one cis-DAM−, two coordinated water molecules, one Cl− anion, and five guest water molecules. The view of the local coordination geometry around the Nd ion is shown in Figure a. Different from 5, lying in a distorted bicapped pentagonal dodecahedron geometry, the center Nd ion is coordinated with ten oxygen atoms from four trans-DAM−, two cis-DAM−, and two water molecules. The bond lengths of Nd−O of 6 are in the range of 2.410(3)−2.710(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported for similar Nd(III) compounds.

elements.content: The coordination mode of trans-DAM− in 6 is identical to that in 5 (Scheme a). A similar corrugated 2D layer is also observed in 6. Nd ions are linked by μ4-trans-DAM− to form a 2D layer on the ac plane with the shortest distance of Nd···Nd being 4.205(8) Å. Interestingly, the cis-DAM− shows another mode in Scheme f, in which one carboxylate group adopts the μ2-η1:η1 mode and the other carboxylate group remains free without connection. Therefore the difference from 5 is that the cis-DAM− in 6 are fixed above and below the layers along the b axis in μ2-bridging mode (Figure b). In 6, the layers are stacked together in an −ABAB− sequence to give a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure c), which is stabilized through the abundant hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S2 and Figure S6, ). Besides the O−H···O hydrogen bonds (O···O, 2.719(7)−2.977(4) Å) from the DAM− and water molecules, Cl− anions also act as the acceptors in the O−H···Cl hydrogen bonds (O···Cl, 3.158(9)−3.330(7) Å) with water molecules.

elements.content: From the topological point of view, each Nd ion in 6 is not only coordinated to four trans-DAM− but also bridged by the cis-DAM− to neighboring Nd ions, so it can be regarded as a 5-connected node. Meanwhile, each trans-DAM− is treated as a 4-connected node. Figure d shows the different 2D (4,5)-connected network from 5 with the Schläfli symbol (3·43·52)(32·44·52·62) (the first symbol for DAM− and the second one for Nd ions).

elements.content: Compound 7 adopts a 2D double-layer structure different from 6, though they have the same molecular formula. In the asymmetric unit of 7, there are one Nd(III) ion, two types of trans-DAM−, two coordinated water molecules, one Cl− anion, and five guest water molecules. The center Nd ion is connected by nine oxygen atoms from three trans-DAM− (i), three trans-DAM− (ii), and two water molecules, exhibiting a distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry (Figure a). The bond lengths of Nd−O of 7 vary from 2.381(5) to 2.729(5) Å, which are comparable to the reported Nd(III) compounds.

elements.content: In the structure of 7, each trans-DAM− (i) acts as a μ3-linker, in which two carboxylate groups adopt μ1-η1:η1 chelating and μ2-η1:η1 bridging modes, respectively (Scheme g), while each trans-DAM− (ii) also coordinates to three Nd ions for the μ1-η0:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups (Scheme h). With these modes, both μ3-trans-DAM− conjoin Nd ions to build a 2D (4,4) rectangular grid layer (Figure b), different from that in 3. Significantly, a couple of central symmetrical layers are further bridged by the μ-(O1, O2, O5, and O6) from the μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups to form a 2D double-layer on the bc plane with the shortest Nd···Nd distance being 4.562(2) Å (Figure c). There are 1D parallelogram-shaped channels of 7.879 Å × 4.937 Å running along the b axis. In the 3D supramolecular framework, which is packed by the double layers in an −AAAA− sequence along the a axis (Figure d), the Cl− counteranions and guest water molecules are consolidated through O−H···O and O−H···Cl hydrogen bonds with the DAM− and coordinated water molecules in the range of 2.773(7)−3.091(8) Å (O···O) and 3.133(6)−3.156(1) Å (O···Cl), respectively (Table S2 and Figure S7, ).

elements.content: Considering the coordination modes in 7, each Nd ion bonded by six trans-DAM− is treated as a 6-connected node. Moreover, two kinds of μ3-trans-DAM− are regarded as 3-connected nodes. The topology of 7 is a novel 2D binodal (3,6)-connected network, and the Schläfli symbol is (42·6)2(48·66·8) (the first symbol for DAM− and the second one for Nd ions) (Figure e). This network is a hitherto undocumented topological structure, as far as we know.

elements.content: From the above descriptions and discussions, the flexible ligands DAM− exhibit various coordination modes from μ1 to μ4, which may provide more possibilities for the construction of the interesting structures and the topologies. In 1, 2, and 4−6 obtained from H2O solvent, one DAM− adopts the same coordination mode, μ4-trans-DAM−, whose two carboxylate groups exhibit the basic μ2-η1:η2 mode (Scheme a). The μ4-trans-DAM− connect Ln ions to generate similar 2D corrugated layers. So the diversity of these structures depends on the different modes of the second DAM− in each compound. For 1 and 2, the cis-DAM− and trans-DAM− (ii) bridge these layers in two manners, μ1-η0:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 (Scheme b,c), to form different 3D frameworks, which are simplified into a binodal (4,5)-connected tcs net and a trinodal (4,6)-connected topology, respectively. With counteranions NO3 − and ClO4 −, the cationic structures in 4 and 5 are not extended for the monodentate μ1-η0:η1 mode of flag-like trans-DAM−(ii). They both exhibit the 2D layers with the sql net. In 6, with smaller counteranions Cl−, the cis-DAM− adopts the bidentate μ2-η1:η1 mode different from 5 locating above and below the layers. So 6 exhibits a 2D structure with a (4,5)-connected network. The results imply that the counteranions have a subtle role in inducing the abundant coordination modes and conformations of DAM− and leading to the different topological structures.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Structures

From the above descriptions and discussions, the flexible ligands DAM- exhibit various coordination modes from μ1 to μ4, which may provide more possibilities for the construction of the interesting structures and the topologies. In 1, 2, and 4-6 obtained from H2O solvent, one DAM- adopts the same coordination mode, μ4-trans-DAM-, whose two carboxylate groups exhibit the basic μ2-η1:η2 mode (Scheme a). The μ4-trans-DAM- connect Ln ions to generate similar 2D corrugated layers. So the diversity of these structures depends on the different modes of the second DAM- in each compound. For 1 and 2, the cis-DAM- and trans-DAM- (ii) bridge these layers in two manners, μ1-η0:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 (Scheme b,c), to form different 3D frameworks, which are simplified into a binodal (4,5)-connected tcs net and a trinodal (4,6)-connected topology, respectively. With counteranions NO3 - and ClO4 -, the cationic structures in 4 and 5 are not extended for the monodentate μ1-η0:η1 mode of flag-like trans-DAM-(ii). They both exhibit the 2D layers with the sql net. In 6, with smaller counteranions Cl-, the cis-DAM- adopts the bidentate μ2-η1:η1 mode different from 5 locating above and below the layers. So 6 exhibits a 2D structure with a (4,5)-connected network. The results imply that the counteranions have a subtle role in inducing the abundant coordination modes and conformations of DAM- and leading to the different topological structures.

elements.content: On the other hand, the DAM− in 3 and 7 from H2O/DMF mixed solvents display fantastic coordination modes. In 3, the μ3-trans-DAM− with μ2-η1:η2 and μ1-η0:η1 modes link La ions to form 2D (4,4) fan-shaped layers, which are further reinforced by bridging oxygen atoms into a 3D open framework with an ant net. Similarly, compound 7 also consists of 2D (4,4) rectangular grid layers with two types of μ3-trans-DAM− (μ1-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1; μ1-η0:η1 and μ2-η1:η1). However, a couple of layers are connected together into a novel 2D double layer, exhibiting a (3,6)-connected network. Obviously, we can surmise that the DMF molecules may adjust the reaction process and can be considered as a factor that gives rise to different modes of DAM−.

elements.content: Moreover, La(III) compounds possess 3D frameworks, and all Nd(III) compounds adopt 2D layers by the comparison of 1−3 and 4−7. The reason may be related to the effect of metal ions as the longer ionic radii of La3+ than that of Nd3+.

elements.content: In the IR spectra of 1−7, the broad bands at 3600−3200 cm−1 indicate the presence of water molecules and the existence of hydrogen-bonding interactions. The absence of the characteristic bands at 1730−1680 cm−1 attributed to the protonated carboxylate groups suggests the complete deprotonation of HDAM. The bands of asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of carboxylate groups are shown in the range of 1665−1581 cm−1 and 1450−1394 cm−1, respectively. The splitting of νas(COO) and νs(COO) reflects that the carboxylate groups of DAM− adopt a variety of coordination modes. In addition, the spectra of 1 and 4 show very strong bands at about 1086 cm−1 due to the ClO4 − anions, and the characteristic bands of NO3 − appear at 1348 cm−1 in that of 5. These facts are consistent with the X-ray diffraction results.
elements.clean_text:
IR and UV-Visible Spectroscopy

In the IR spectra of 1-7, the broad bands at 3600-3200 cm-1 indicate the presence of water molecules and the existence of hydrogen-bonding interactions. The absence of the characteristic bands at 1730-1680 cm-1 attributed to the protonated carboxylate groups suggests the complete deprotonation of HDAM. The bands of asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of carboxylate groups are shown in the range of 1665-1581 cm-1 and 1450-1394 cm-1, respectively. The splitting of νas(COO) and νs(COO) reflects that the carboxylate groups of DAM- adopt a variety of coordination modes. In addition, the spectra of 1 and 4 show very strong bands at about 1086 cm-1 due to the ClO4 - anions, and the characteristic bands of NO3 - appear at 1348 cm-1 in that of 5. These facts are consistent with the X-ray diffraction results.

elements.content: In the UV−visible absorption spectra of 1−7 (Figure ), the strong absorption bands at about 220 nm are ascribed to the ligand-centered transitions of DAM−. The bands are slightly blue-shifted compared with that of HDAM (230 nm), indicating that the coordination with Ln ions enlarges the energy gaps in the conjugated systems of DAM−. However, the obvious difference of the spectra between 1−3 and 4−7 is caused by the characteristic absorption bands of Nd(III). The bands in the range of 300−1000 nm can be assigned to the corresponding electronic transitions of Nd3+ from the ground state 4I9/2 to the excited states 2I11/2, 4G7/2, 4G9/2, 2G7/2, 4G5/2, 4F7/2, 4S3/2, 2H9/2, 4F5/2, and 4F3/2.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent properties of HDAM and 4−7 were investigated at room temperature (Figure S8, ). Upon excitation with 350 nm, the HDAM ligands exhibit a luminescent emission band at 422 nm, which is assigned to intraligand π*−π transition. Under an excitation of 350 nm, compounds 4−7 display quite similar characteristic emission bands of Nd(III) in the near-infrared region, whereas the emission bands based on the HDAM are not observed. The absence of ligand-based emission bands indicates that the energy transfers from HDAM ligands to Nd(III) centers, which is the well-known “antenna effect”. In Figure S8, the weak emission band at about 912 nm, the strong band at 1059 nm, and the weak band at 1333 nm in the near-infrared region are attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4F3/2 → 4I11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4I13/2 transitions of Nd3+ ions, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of HDAM and 4-7 were investigated at room temperature (Figure S8, ). Upon excitation with 350 nm, the HDAM ligands exhibit a luminescent emission band at 422 nm, which is assigned to intraligand π*-π transition. Under an excitation of 350 nm, compounds 4-7 display quite similar characteristic emission bands of Nd(III) in the near-infrared region, whereas the emission bands based on the HDAM are not observed. The absence of ligand-based emission bands indicates that the energy transfers from HDAM ligands to Nd(III) centers, which is the well-known "antenna effect". In Figure S8, the weak emission band at about 912 nm, the strong band at 1059 nm, and the weak band at 1333 nm in the near-infrared region are attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4F3/2 → 4I11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4I13/2 transitions of Nd3+ ions, respectively.

elements.content: The structures of 4−6 are very similar, so 1−4 and 7 were selected to examine the thermal stability (Figure ). For 1, in the first step from 45 to 390 °C, the observed weight loss of 13.5% is close to the calculated value (12.9%), which corresponds to the release of guest and coordinated water molecules. The second step began at 390 °C, during which the organic ligands started to release progressively. TGA curves of 2−4 and 7 also exhibit two similar main weight loss steps. The total observed weight losses based on the removal of water molecules in the first steps (22.0%, 18.2%, 11.5%, and 19.3%) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (23.1%, 16.6%, 12.8%, and 18.8%), respectively. The decomposition for the structures in 2 and 7 occurs starting at 310 °C. Meanwhile, the decomposition temperature is 340 °C for 3 and 4. For the slopes of the second steps, the observed weight losses are all slightly smaller than the theoretical ones, which suggest that the decomposition processes are not complete at 700 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

The structures of 4-6 are very similar, so 1-4 and 7 were selected to examine the thermal stability (Figure ). For 1, in the first step from 45 to 390 °C, the observed weight loss of 13.5% is close to the calculated value (12.9%), which corresponds to the release of guest and coordinated water molecules. The second step began at 390 °C, during which the organic ligands started to release progressively. TGA curves of 2-4 and 7 also exhibit two similar main weight loss steps. The total observed weight losses based on the removal of water molecules in the first steps (22.0%, 18.2%, 11.5%, and 19.3%) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (23.1%, 16.6%, 12.8%, and 18.8%), respectively. The decomposition for the structures in 2 and 7 occurs starting at 310 °C. Meanwhile, the decomposition temperature is 340 °C for 3 and 4. For the slopes of the second steps, the observed weight losses are all slightly smaller than the theoretical ones, which suggest that the decomposition processes are not complete at 700 °C.

elements.content: In summary, a series of La(III) and Nd(III) compounds with novel topological structures were obtained with the flexible HDMA under a rational synthetic strategy. In 1−7, the DAM− in trans- and cis- conformations afford those intriguing modes in the formation of these specific structures. For 3D structures 1−3, when the guest molecules are removed from the channels, there is approximately 31.2%, 33.0%, and 29.9% void space per unit volume, respectively. Meanwhile, compounds 4−7, containing infinite 2D layers, are further linked together by hydrogen-bonding interactions into 3D supramolecular frameworks. Clearly, the difference among these structures indicates that various coordination modes of DAM− are to a certain extent influenced by solvent molecules, counteranions as well as metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a series of La(III) and Nd(III) compounds with novel topological structures were obtained with the flexible HDMA under a rational synthetic strategy. In 1-7, the DAM- in trans- and cis- conformations afford those intriguing modes in the formation of these specific structures. For 3D structures 1-3, when the guest molecules are removed from the channels, there is approximately 31.2%, 33.0%, and 29.9% void space per unit volume, respectively. Meanwhile, compounds 4-7, containing infinite 2D layers, are further linked together by hydrogen-bonding interactions into 3D supramolecular frameworks. Clearly, the difference among these structures indicates that various coordination modes of DAM- are to a certain extent influenced by solvent molecules, counteranions as well as metal ions.

{[La(<italic toggle="yes">trans</italic>-DAM)(<italic toggle="yes">cis</italic>-DAM)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)·3H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of La(ClO4)3·6H2O (0.2 mmol) and HDAM (0.5 mmol) was added to 5.0 mL H2O. The pH value was adjusted to 3.0 with HClO4 (1.0 mol/L) and KOH (1.0 mol/L). After being stirred for 30 min, the precipitate was filtrated. Colorless prism crystals were isolated with 86% yield after 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H24ClN4O17La: C, 24.20; H, 3.48; N, 8.06 wt %. Found: C, 24.03; H, 3.55; N, 8.12 wt %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3375b, 3130m, 2999vw, 1653s, 1593vs, 1441s, 1402s, 1305s, 1175m, 1113m, 1086s, 975vw, 934w, 792w, 706m, 623m, 437w.

A mixture of LaCl3·6H2O (0.2 mmol) and HDAM (0.5 mmol) was added to 5.0 mL of H2O. The pH value was adjusted to 3.0 with HCl (1.0 mol/L) and KOH (1.0 mol/L). After being stirred for 30 min, the precipitate was filtrated. Colorless block crystals were obtained with 71% yield after a week. Anal. Calcd for C21H46N6O26La2: C, 23.43; H, 4.31; N, 7.81 wt %. Found: C, 23.33; H, 4.40; N, 7.85 wt %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400b, 3160m, 3002w, 2991vw, 1644s, 1584vs, 1441 m, 1398s, 1305m, 1174m, 1023w, 937w, 794w, 709m, 442w.

A mixture of LaCl3·6H2O (0.2 mmol) and HDAM (0.5 mmol) was dissolved in H2O and DMF (5:1, 6.0 mL). The pH value was adjusted to 3.0 with HCl (1.0 mol/L) and KOH (1.0 mol/L). Found: C, 26.04; H, 4.13; N, 8.50 wt %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3387b, 3160m, 3002w, 2961vw, 1670s, 1596vs, 1442m, 1403s, 1318m, 1174m, 887w, 752w, 710m, 638m, 426w.

The synthesis procedures were similar to that of 1 except that La(ClO4)3·6H2O was replaced by Nd(ClO4)3·6H2O (for 4) and Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (for 5). Caution! Perchlorate compounds can be explosive. Only a small amount of materials should be prepared and handled with great care.

After being stirred for 30 min, the precipitate was filtrated. Colorless prism crystals were isolated with 86% yield after 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H24ClN4O17La: C, 24.20; H, 3.48; N, 8.06 wt %. cln_elements.content:
The coordination modes of trans-DAM− and cis-DAM− are displayed in Scheme , parts a and b, respectively. Both carboxylate groups of each trans-DAM− exhibit one kind of bridging mode, μ2-η1:η2, and both carboxylate groups of each cis-DAM− show the μ1-η0:η1 mode. In detail, La ions in 1 are doubly bridged by μ-O3 from trans-DAM− to form a [La2O2] chain running along the a axis, in which the shortest La···La distance is 4.608(6) Å. The neighboring [La2O2] chains are connected by μ4-trans-DAM− to generate 2D corrugated layers (Figure b) on the ac plane, which are further linked by μ2-cis-DAM− to form an open framework with 3D infinite intersected channels (Figure c,d). The dimensions of the largest channels are approximately 10.347 Å × 10.347 Å along the c axis. All of the channels are occupied by the counteranions ClO4 − and guest water molecules. There are strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated oxygen atoms of cis-DAM− with the O···O distances in the range of 2.769(3)−2.967(1) Å (Figure S1, ). The effective free volume of the channels without these guest molecules is estimated to be 790.4 Å3 by PLATON software, almost 31.2% of the per unit cell volume of 2530.2 Å3.

The trans-DAM− (i) shows the same bis-μ2-η1:η2 mode (Scheme a) as that in 1. The same 2D corrugated layers on the ac plane are also observed in 2 with the shortest La···La distance being 4.439(8) Å. However, different from 1, there are no cis-DAM− ligands, and both carboxylate groups of the other trans-DAM− (ii) in 2 adopt the μ2-η1:η1 bridging mode (Scheme c). The 2D layers are cross-linked by the μ4-trans-DAM− (ii) to give a 3D framework (Figure b) with 2D rhombic channels, which propagate infinitely along the a and c axes with the sizes of approximately 9.049 Å × 7.459 Å and 10.298 Å × 7.439 Å, respectively (Figure c). Furthermore, the structure is stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the guest molecules in the channels with O···O distances of 2.762(8)−3.118(8) Å (Table S2 and Figure S2, ). After removal of these molecules in the channels, the effective free volume is approximately 33.0% of the crystal volume (686.2 Å3 out of the 2081.3 Å3 per unit cell volume) by PLATON.

Scheme d depicts the different coordination modes of carboxylate groups of the unique trans-DAM−in 3: μ2-η1:η2 and μ1-η0:η1. It is interesting that each La ion is connected by four trans-DAM− in μ3-mode to generate a 2D (4,4) fan-shaped grid layer on the ab plane (Figure b). These layers are further pillared via sharing the μ-O3 of trans-DAM− in an −ABAB− sequence to form a 3D structure with the shortest Nd···Nd distance of 4.556(6) Å, and each layer is central symmetrical to the next one, as presented in Figure c. There are 1D honeycomb channels of 10.899 Å × 10.658 Å along the c axis in 3 (Figure d), where the anion Cl− and guest water molecules are consolidated through hydrogen bonds with the O···O and O···Cl distances in the range of 2.782(8)−3.222(5) Å and 2.814(0) Å, respectively (Table S2 and Figure S3, ). The hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the disordered water molecules have not been discussed here. On the basis of a PLATON calculation, the framework of 3 possesses a 752.7 Å3 (29.9% of the whole unit cell volume 2520.2 Å3) solvent-accessible void space without the counteranions and guest water molecules.

Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of HDAM and 4−7 were investigated at room temperature (Figure S8, ). Upon excitation with 350 nm, the HDAM ligands exhibit a luminescent emission band at 422 nm, which is assigned to intraligand π*−π transition. Under an excitation of 350 nm, compounds 4−7 display quite similar characteristic emission bands of Nd(III) in the near-infrared region, whereas the emission bands based on the HDAM are not observed. The absence of ligand-based emission bands indicates that the energy transfers from HDAM ligands to Nd(III) centers, which is the well-known “antenna effect”. In Figure S8, the weak emission band at about 912 nm, the strong band at 1059 nm, and the weak band at 1333 nm in the near-infrared region are attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4F3/2 → 4I11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4I13/2 transitions of Nd3+ ions, respectively.

Thermal Stability

The structures of 4−6 are very similar, so 1−4 and 7 were selected to examine the thermal stability (Figure ). For 1, in the first step from 45 to 390 °C, the observed weight loss of 13.5% is close to the calculated value (12.9%), which corresponds to the release of guest and coordinated water molecules. The second step began at 390 °C, during which the organic ligands started to release progressively. TGA curves of 2−4 and 7 also exhibit two similar main weight loss steps. The total observed weight losses based on the removal of water molecules in the first steps (22.0%, 18.2%, 11.5%, and 19.3%) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (23.1%, 16.6%, 12.8%, and 18.8%), respectively. The decomposition for the structures in 2 and 7 occurs starting at 310 °C. Meanwhile, the decomposition temperature is 340 °C for 3 and 4. For the slopes of the second steps, the observed weight losses are all slightly smaller than the theoretical ones, which suggest that the decomposition processes are not complete at 700 °C.
